metadata.section_title: Validity requirements for Domestic Worker in a Private Household

chunks.text:
### Validity requirements for Domestic Worker in a Private Household

DW 1.1. A person applying for permission to stay as a Domestic Worker in a Private Household must apply on the gov.uk website on the specified form FLR(IR).

1.   DW 1.2. An application for permission to stay as a Domestic Worker in a Private Household must meet all the following requirements: 
    1.   (a) the applicant must be in the UK on the date of application; and
    2.   (b) any fee and Immigration Health Charge must have been paid; and
    3.   (c) the applicant must have provided biometrics when required; and
    4.   (d) the applicant must have provided a valid passport or other travel document which satisfactorily establishes their identity and nationality.

DW 1.2A. The applicant must have entered the UK with valid entry clearance as a Domestic Worker in a Private Household under the rules in place before 6 April 2012 and have held permission to stay as a Domestic Worker in a Private Household since they entered on this route.

DW 1.3. An application which does not meet all the validity requirements for a Domestic Worker in a Private Household may be rejected as invalid and not considered.
chunks.summary: Applicants seeking permission to stay as Domestic Workers in a Private Household must apply online using form FLR(IR), ensuring they are in the UK, have paid fees and Immigration Health Charge, provided biometrics, and hold a valid travel document. They must have entered the UK with valid entry clearance under pre-2012 rules and maintained lawful permission; applications not meeting these requirements will be rejected.

    4.   (d) the applicant must have provided a valid passport or other travel document which satisfactorily establishes their identity and nationality.

DW 1.2A. The applicant must have entered the UK with valid entry clearance as a Domestic Worker in a Private Household under the rules in place before 6 April 2012 and have held permission to stay as a Domestic Worker in a Private Household since they entered on this route.

DW 1.3. An application which does not meet all the validity requirements for a Domestic Worker in a Private Household may be rejected as invalid and not considered.

metadata.section_title: Suitability requirements for a Domestic Worker in a Private Household

chunks.text:
### Suitability requirements for a Domestic Worker in a Private Household

DW 2.1. The applicant must not fall for refusal under Part Suitability.

DW 2.2. The applicant must not be in the UK in breach of immigration laws except that, where the Exceptions for overstayers section of Part Suitability applies, any current period of overstaying will be disregarded.
chunks.summary: This provision applies to domestic workers applying for entry or permission to stay in private households. They must meet suitability criteria, including not breaching immigration laws, unless an overstaying exception applies; any overstaying is generally disregarded if covered by the exception.

metadata.section_title: Eligibility requirements for a Domestic Worker in a Private Household

chunks.text:
### Eligibility requirements for a Domestic Worker in a Private Household

DW 3.1. DELETED.

DW 3.2 DELETED.

DW 3.3. The applicant must be employed for at least 30 hours per week in a private household under the same roof as the employer or in the same household as the employer for the duration of their employment.

DW 3.4. The applicant must have agreed in writing, the terms and conditions of their employment in the UK and must provide evidence, in the form set out in Appendix Domestic Worker Statement, which must be fully completed and signed by both parties.

DW 3.5. The decision maker must be satisfied that the applicant’s conditions of employment mean that they will be paid at least the UK National Minimum Wage throughout their employment in the UK.

DW 3.6. The applicant must not intend to take any form of employment except as a Domestic Worker in a Private Household.
chunks.summary: This provision applies to domestic workers in private households seeking immigration status. The applicant must be employed for at least 30 hours/week, have a written employment agreement, and be paid at least the UK National Minimum Wage. They must also intend only to work as a domestic worker in a private household; no other employment is permitted.

chunks.text:
### Financial requirement for Domestic Worker in a Private Household

DW 4.1. The decision maker must be satisfied that the applicant can and will adequately maintain and accommodate themselves, and any dependants in the UK or applying for entry clearance, without recourse to public funds.

DW 4.2. Funds must be shown as specified in Appendix Finance.
chunks.summary: This provision applies to domestic workers seeking entry clearance or extension. Applicants must demonstrate they can adequately support and accommodate themselves and dependants in the UK without recourse to public funds, meeting the financial criteria set out in Appendix Finance.

metadata.section_title: Decision on an application as a Domestic Worker in a Private Household

chunks.text:
### Decision on an application as a Domestic Worker in a Private Household

DW 5.1. If the decision maker is satisfied that all of the suitability and eligibility requirements for permission to stay as a Domestic Worker in a Private Household are met the application will be granted, otherwise the application will be refused.

DW 5.2. If the application is refused, the person can apply for an Administrative Review under Appendix AR: Administrative Review.
chunks.summary: This provision applies to applicants seeking permission to stay as Domestic Workers in private households. Applications are granted if all suitability and eligibility requirements are met; otherwise, they are refused, with an entitlement to request an Administrative Review.

metadata.section_title: Period of grant for a Domestic Worker in a Private Household

chunks.text:
### Period of grant for a Domestic Worker in a Private Household

DW 6.1 The applicant will be granted permission to stay for 12 months.

DW 6.2. Where the application is decided before the current permission expires, the extension of stay granted may be for a period of 12 months plus the time remaining before the current permission expires (for example, if the application is decided on March 31st and the current permission does not expire until April 30th, an additional period of one month will be granted).
chunks.summary: This provision applies to domestic workers in private households. It grants a 12-month permission to stay, which may be extended to include any remaining valid period of the current permission if an extension is decided before expiry.

metadata.section_title: Conditions of grant for a Domestic Worker in a Private Household

chunks.text:
### Conditions of grant for a Domestic Worker in a Private Household

1.   DW 6.3 The grant will be subject to the following conditions: 
    1.   (a) no access to public funds; and
    2.   (b) no work except as a domestic worker in a private household; and
    3.   (c) study is permitted, subject to the ATAS condition in Appendix ATAS.

DW 6.4. The applicant is permitted to change employer, without notifying the Home Office, within the validity of their permission as a Domestic Worker in a Private Household.
chunks.summary: This provision applies to domestic workers in private households. They must not access public funds, can only work as domestic workers, and may study with ATAS approval; changing employers within validity is permitted without notification.

chunks.text:
### Validity requirements for settlement as a Domestic Worker in a Private Household

DW 7.1. A person applying for settlement as a Domestic Worker in a Private Household must apply on the gov.uk website on the specified form “Settle in the UK in various immigration categories: form SET(O)”.

1.   DW 7.2. An application for settlement as a Domestic Worker in a Private Household must meet all the following requirements: 
    1.   (a) any fee must have been paid; and
    2.   (b) the applicant must have provided biometrics when required; and
    3.   (c) the applicant must have provided a passport or other travel document which satisfactorily establishes their identity and nationality; and
    4.   (d) the applicant must be in the UK on the date of application.

DW 7.3. The applicant must have, or have last been granted, permission as a Domestic Worker in a Private Household.

DW 7.4. An application which does not meet all the validity requirements for settlement as a Domestic Worker in a Private Household may be rejected as invalid and not considered.
chunks.summary: Applicants seeking settlement as a Domestic Worker in a Private Household must apply online using form SET(O), pay fees, provide biometrics, and demonstrate identity while being in the UK, with existing valid permission; failure to meet these criteria results in rejection.

metadata.section_title: Qualifying period for settlement as a Domestic Worker in a Private Household

chunks.text:
### Qualifying period for settlement as a Domestic Worker in a Private Household

DW 9.1. The applicant must have entered the UK with a valid entry clearance as a Domestic Worker in a Private Household under the Rules in place before 6 April 2012.

DW 9.2. The applicant must have spent a continuous period of 5 years lawfully in the UK as a Domestic Worker in a Private Household under the Rules in place before 6 April 2012.

DW 9.3 The applicant must not have worked in the UK except as a Domestic Worker in a Private Household.

DW 9.4. The applicant must continue to be required by their employer for employment as a Domestic Worker in a Private Household.
chunks.summary: Applicants must have entered the UK legally before 6 April 2012, worked continuously for five years solely as a Domestic Worker in a Private Household, and remain required by their employer. Exceptions or additional conditions are not specified.

### English language requirement for settlement as a Domestic Worker in a Private Household

DW 11.1. Unless an exemption applies, the applicant must show English language ability on the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages in speaking and listening to at least level B1.

DW 11.2. The applicant must show they meet the English language requirement as specified in Appendix English Language.

metadata.section_title: Validity requirements for a dependant partner or dependant child of a Domestic Worker in a Private Household route

chunks.text:
### Validity requirements for a dependant partner or dependant child of a Domestic Worker in a Private Household route

DW 14.1. A person applying for entry clearance or permission to stay as a dependant partner or dependant child of a Domestic Worker in a Private Household must apply on gov.uk on the specified form Application to extend stay in the UK: FLR (IR).

1.   DW 14.2. An application for entry clearance or permission to stay as a partner or child of a Domestic Worker in a Private Household must meet all the following requirements: 
    1.   (a) any fee and Immigration Health Charge must have been paid; and
    2.   (b) the applicant must have provided biometrics when required; and
    3.   (c) the applicant must have provided a passport or other travel document which satisfactorily establishes their identity and nationality; and
    4.   (d) the applicant must be applying as a partner or child of a person (P) who: 
        1.   (i) has made a valid application for permission to stay in the UK as a Domestic Worker in a Private Household that has not been decided; or
        2.   (ii) has entry clearance or permission to stay as Domestic Worker in a Private Household; or
        3.   (iii) is settled or has become a British citizen, providing that P had permission as a Domestic Worker in a Private Household when they settled and the applicant either had permission as their partner or child at that time or the applicant is applying as a child of P and the applicant was born in the UK before P settled.

DW 14.3. If the applicant is applying as a dependant partner, they must be aged 18 or over on the date of application.

DW 14.4. If applying for permission to stay, the applicant must be in the UK on the date of application.

1.   DW 14.4A. If applying for permission to stay, the applicant must not have, or have last been granted, permission: 
    1.   (a) as a Visitor; or
    2.   (b) as a Short-term Student.

DW 14.5. An application which does not meet all of the validity requirements for a partner or child of a Domestic Worker in a Private Household may be rejected as invalid and not considered.

They must submit a valid application, meet fee, biometrics, identity, and relationship criteria, and be linked to a currently or previously valid UK domestic worker who is settled, a British citizen, or has pending/sheduled applications.

### Validity requirements for a dependant partner or dependant child of a Domestic Worker in a Private Household route

DW 14.1. A person applying for entry clearance or permission to stay as a dependant partner or dependant child of a Domestic Worker in a Private Household must apply on gov.uk on the specified form Application to extend stay in the UK: FLR (IR).

1.   DW 14.2. An application for entry clearance or permission to stay as a partner or child of a Domestic Worker in a Private Household must meet all the following requirements: 
    1.   (a) any fee and Immigration Health Charge must have been paid; and
    2.   (b) the applicant must have provided biometrics when required; and
    3.   (c) the applicant must have provided a passport or other travel document which satisfactorily establishes their identity and nationality; and
    4.   (d) the applicant must be applying as a partner or child of a person (P) who: 
        1.   (i) has made a valid application for permission to stay in the UK as a Domestic Worker in a Private Household that has not been decided; or
        2.   (ii) has entry clearance or permission to stay as Domestic Worker in a Private Household; or
        3.   (iii) is settled or has become a British citizen, providing that P had permission as a Domestic Worker in a Private Household when they settled and the applicant either had permission as their partner or child at that time or the applicant is applying as a child of P and the applicant was born in the UK before P settled.

DW 14.3. If the applicant is applying as a dependant partner, they must be aged 18 or over on the date of application.

DW 14.4. If applying for permission to stay, the applicant must be in the UK on the date of application.

1.   DW 14.4A. If applying for permission to stay, the applicant must not have, or have last been granted, permission: 
    1.   (a) as a Visitor; or
    2.   (b) as a Short-term Student.

DW 14.5. An application which does not meet all of the validity requirements for a partner or child of a Domestic Worker in a Private Household may be rejected as invalid and not considered.

### Suitability requirements for a dependant partner or dependent child on the Domestic Worker in a Private Household route.

DW 15.1. The applicant must not fall for refusal under Part Suitability.

1.   DW 15.2. If applying for permission to stay the applicant must not be: 
    1.   (a) in breach of immigration laws, except that where the Exceptions for overstayers section of Part Suitability applies, that period of overstaying will be disregarded; or
    2.   (b) on immigration bail.

chunks.text:
### Entry requirements for a dependant partner or dependant child of a Domestic Worker in a Private Household

DW 16.1. A person seeking to come to the UK as a partner or child of a Domestic Worker in a Private Household must apply for and obtain entry clearance as a partner or child of a Domestic Worker in a Private Household before they arrive in the UK.

DW 16.2. A person applying for entry clearance as the partner or child of a Domestic Worker in a Private Household must, if Appendix Tuberculosis applies, provide a valid medical certificate confirming that they have undergone screening for active pulmonary tuberculosis and that this tuberculosis is not present in them.
chunks.summary: Dependants of Domestic Workers in Private Households must apply for entry clearance before arriving in the UK and may need to provide TB screening if applicable.

metadata.section_title: Relationship requirement for a dependant partner of a Domestic Worker in a Private Household

chunks.text:
### Relationship requirement for a dependant partner of a Domestic Worker in a Private Household

1.   DW 17.1. The applicant must be the partner of a person (P) where one of the following applies: 
    1.   (a) P has permission as a Domestic Worker in a Private Household; or
    2.   (b) P is, at the same time, applying for (and is granted) permission as a Domestic Worker in a Private Household; or
    3.   (c) P is settled or has become a British citizen, providing P had permission on the Domestic Worker in a Private Household route when they settled, and the applicant had permission as P’s partner at that time.

1.   DW 17.2. If the applicant and their Domestic Worker in a Private Household partner are not married or in a civil partnership, all of the following requirements must be met: 
    1.   (a) they must have been living together in a relationship similar to marriage or civil partnership for at least the two years before the date of application; and
    2.   (b) any previous relationship of the applicant or their Domestic Worker in a Private Household partner with another person must have permanently broken down; and
    3.   (c) the applicant and their Domestic Worker in a Private Household partner must not be so closely related that they would not be allowed to marry or form a civil partnership in the UK.

DW 17.3. The relationship between the applicant and their Domestic Worker in a Private Household partner must be genuine and subsisting.

DW 17.4. The applicant and their Domestic Worker in a Private Household partner must intend to live together throughout the applicant’s stay in the UK.
chunks.summary: The provision applies to dependants of Domestic Workers in private households seeking partner status. Applicants must prove a genuine, subsisting relationship, meet specific duration and breakup conditions if unmarried, and be connected to a valid Domestic Worker or settled individual. Close genetic relations disqualify, with additional living and relationship requirements outlined.

chunks.text:
### Financial requirement for a dependent partner or a dependant child of a Domestic Worker in a Private Household

DW 20.1 The decision maker must be satisfied that there will be adequate maintenance and accommodation for the applicant, the person on the Domestic Worker in a Private Household route, and any other dependants in the UK, without recourse to public funds.
chunks.summary: This provision applies to dependent partners or children of Domestic Workers in a Private Household. It requires applicants to demonstrate adequate maintenance and accommodation without recourse to public funds. No specific income thresholds are outlined, but sufficient financial resources must be proven.

chunks.text:
### Decision on an application as a dependant partner or a dependant child of a Domestic Worker in a Private Household

DW 21.1 If the decision maker is satisfied that all the suitability and eligibility requirements are met for a dependent partner or a dependant child of a Domestic Worker in a Private Household the application will be granted, otherwise the application will be refused.

DW 21.2. If the application is refused the person can apply for an Administrative Review under Appendix AR: Administrative Review.

metadata.section_title: Period of grant for a dependant partner or a dependant child of a Domestic Worker in a Private Household

chunks.text:
### Period of grant for a dependant partner or a dependant child of a Domestic Worker in a Private Household

1.   DW 22.1. A partner will be granted: 
    1.   (a) permission which ends on the same date as their partner’s permission as a Domestic Worker in a Private Household; or
    2.   (b) 2 years’ permission if the Domestic Worker in a Private Household was (or is being) granted settlement as a Domestic Worker in a Private Household.

DW 22.2. A child will be granted permission which ends on the same date as whichever of their parents’ permission ends first, unless both parents have (or are being granted) settlement or British Citizenship, in which case the child will be granted permission for 30 months.
chunks.summary: Dependants of Domestic Workers in a Private Household are granted permission aligned with the worker’s stay; partners' permission ends on the same date as the worker’s, or up to 2 years if the worker has settlement. Children’s permission ends with the earliest parent’s, or 30 months if both parents have settlement or British Citizenship.

chunks.text:
### Validity requirements for settlement as a dependant partner or a dependant child of a Domestic Worker in a Private Household

DW 23.1. A person applying for settlement as a dependant partner or child of a Domestic Worker in a Private Household must apply online on the gov.uk website on the specified form SET (O).

1.   DW 23.2. An application for settlement as a partner or child of a Domestic Worker in a Private Household must meet all the following requirements: 
    1.   (a) any fee must have been paid; and
    2.   (b) the applicant must have provided biometrics when required; and
    3.   (c) the applicant must have provided a passport or other travel document which satisfactorily establishes their identity and nationality; and
    4.   (d) the applicant must be in the UK on the date of application; and
    5.   (e) the applicant must be applying as a partner or child of a person (P) who: 
        1.   (i) has made a valid application for settlement in the UK as a Domestic Worker in a Private Household that has not been decided; or
        2.   (ii) is settled or has become a British citizen, providing P had permission as a Domestic Worker in a Private Household when they settled and the applicant either had permission as their partner or child at that time or the applicant is applying as a child of P and the applicant was born in the UK before P settled.

DW 23.3. DELETED.

DW 23.4. An application which does not meet all the validity requirements for settlement as a partner or child of a Domestic Worker in a Private Household may be rejected as invalid and not considered.
chunks.summary: Applicants seeking settlement as a dependant partner or child of a Domestic Worker in a Private Household must submit an online application, pay fees, provide biometrics, and confirm identity, with eligibility tied to the sponsor’s immigration status and current presence in the UK. Conditions include that the sponsor's settlement application is pending or they are settled or British, with exceptions for UK-born children.

chunks.text:
### Suitability requirements for a dependant partner or a dependant child of a Domestic Worker in a Private Household

DW 24.1. The applicant must not fall for refusal under Part Suitability.

1.   DW 24.2. The applicant must not be: 
    1.   (a) in breach of immigration laws, except that where the Exceptions for overstayers section of Part Suitability applies, that period of overstaying will be disregarded; or
    2.   (b) on immigration bail.
chunks.summary: This provision applies to dependants of Domestic Workers in a Private Household. Dependant partners or children must meet suitability criteria, including not breaching immigration laws (unless exceptions apply) or being on bail. It ensures only suitable applicants are granted entry or stay.

metadata.section_title: Relationship requirements for a dependant partner or a dependant child of a Domestic Worker in a Private Household

chunks.text:
### Relationship requirements for a dependant partner or a dependant child of a Domestic Worker in a Private Household

1.   DW 25.1. The applicant must be the partner or child of a person (P) where one of the following applies: 
    1.   (a) P is, at the same time, being granted settlement as a Domestic Worker in a Private Household; or
    2.   (b) P is settled or has become a British citizen, providing P had permission as a Domestic Worker in a Private Household when they settled, and the applicant either: 
        1.   i) had permission as P’s partner or child at that time; or
        2.   ii) is applying as the child of P, and was born in the UK before P settled.

1.   DW 25.1A. The applicant must either: 
    1.   (a) have last been granted permission as a dependent partner or dependent child of the person (P) in DW 25.1; or
    2.   (b) have been born in the UK and be applying as a child of the person (P) in DW 25.1.

1.   DW 25.2. If applying as a child, the applicant must meet the relationship requirement for settlement in Appendix Children.
chunks.summary: This provision applies to dependants (partners or children) of Domestic Workers in a Private Household. Dependants must demonstrate a relationship to a settled or currently permitted Domestic Worker, with specific rules for those born in the UK or applying as dependants; exceptions include UK-born children or those previously granted dependent status.

        2.   ii) is applying as the child of P, and was born in the UK before P settled.

1.   DW 25.1A. The applicant must either: 
    1.   (a) have last been granted permission as a dependent partner or dependent child of the person (P) in DW 25.1; or

1.   DW 25.2. If applying as a child, the applicant must meet the relationship requirement for settlement in Appendix Children.

chunks.text:
### Requirements for settlement as a dependent child of a Domestic Worker in a Private Household

1.   DW 27A.1. The applicant must meet the following requirements for a dependent child in Appendix Children: 
    1.   (a) care requirement; and
    2.   (b) age and independent life requirement.
chunks.summary: Dependent children of domestic workers in private households must meet the criteria for care and age/independent living as set out in Appendix Children to qualify for settlement, subject to specific eligibility conditions.

metadata.section_title: Qualifying period requirement for settlement as a dependant partner of a Domestic Worker in a Private Household route

chunks.text:
### Qualifying period requirement for settlement as a dependant partner of a Domestic Worker in a Private Household route

DW 28.1. The applicant must have spent a continuous period of 5 years in the UK with permission as a dependant partner of the person (P) in DW 25.1.
chunks.summary: This provision applies to dependants of domestic workers in private households seeking settlement. They must have spent 5 continuous years in the UK with permission as a dependant partner of the relevant worker. The period must be uninterrupted; exceptions are not specified.

metadata.section_title: English language requirement for settlement by a dependant partner or dependent child of a domestic worker in a Private Household

chunks.text:
### English language requirement for settlement by a dependant partner or dependent child of a domestic worker in a Private Household

DW 30.1. Unless an exemption applies, the applicant must show English language ability on the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages in speaking and listening of at least level B1.

DW 30.2. The applicant must show they meet the English language requirement as specified in Appendix English Language.
chunks.summary: Dependant partners or children of domestic workers applying for settlement must demonstrate English language proficiency at B1 level in speaking and listening, unless exempted, as per Appendix English Language.

### Knowledge of life in the UK requirement for settlement by a dependant partner or dependant child of a Domestic Worker in a Private Household

DW 31.1. If the applicant is aged 18 or over at the date of application, they must meet the Knowledge of Life in the UK requirement as specified Appendix KOL UK.
chunks.summary: Dependants aged 18 or over of a Domestic Worker in a Private Household seeking settlement must meet the Knowledge of Life in the UK requirement outlined in Appendix KOL UK, as a key eligibility condition. There are no specified exceptions, but applicants must fulfill this requirement to qualify for settlement.

metadata.section_title: Decision on an application for settlement as a dependant partner or dependant child of a Domestic Worker in a Private Household

chunks.text:
### Decision on an application for settlement as a dependant partner or dependant child of a Domestic Worker in a Private Household

DW 32.1. If the decision maker is satisfied all the suitability and eligibility requirements are met for settlement as a dependant partner or dependant child of a Domestic Worker in a Private Household, the applicant will be granted settlement, otherwise the application will be refused.

DW 32.2 If the application is refused the person can apply for an Administrative Review under Appendix AR: Administrative Review.

Print this page
